<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On August&nbsp;1, 2005, we filed applications with the FCC requesting renewal of the broadcast licenses for WCGV-TV and WVTV-TV in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.&#160; On November&nbsp;1, 2005, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition filed a petition to deny these renewal applications.&#160; On June&nbsp;13, 2007, the Video Division of the FCC denied the petition to deny, and subsequently, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition filed a petition for reconsideration of that decision, which we opposed.&#160; In July&nbsp;2008, the Video Division granted the renewal application of WVTV-TV and separately denied the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition&#146;s petition for reconsideration.&#160; On August&nbsp;11, 2008, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition and another organization filed another petition for reconsideration of the decision, which we opposed.&#160; On January&nbsp;12, 2010, the FCC dismissed the second petition for reconsideration.&#160; On February&nbsp;16, 2010, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition filed an application for review of the January&nbsp;2010 dismissal decision, which we opposed.&#160; On December&nbsp;12, 2010, the FCC dismissed the application for review.&#160; On January&nbsp;11, 2011, the Milwaukee Public Interest Media Coalition filed a second application for review seeking review of the December&nbsp;2010 dismissal decision, which we opposed.&#160; The WCGV-TV renewal of license application remains pending.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On February&nbsp;27, 2006, an individual named James Pennino purportedly filed a petition to deny the license renewal application of WUCW-TV in Minneapolis, Minnesota.&#160; Despite not having found any official record of the filing, we opposed the petition and the renewal application was granted on May&nbsp;14, 2010.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Action on many license renewal applications, including those we have filed, has been delayed because of the pendency of complaints that programming aired by the various networks contained indecent material and complaints regarding alleged violations of sponsorship identification rules.&#160; We cannot predict when the FCC will address these complaints and act on the renewal applications.&#160; We continue to have operating authority until final action is taken on our renewal applications.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC has made it difficult for us to predict the impact on our license renewals from allegations related to the airing of indecent material that may arise in the ordinary course of our business.&#160; For example, on Veterans&#146; Day in November&nbsp;2004, we preempted (did not air) &#147;Saving Private Ryan&#148;, a program that was aired during ABC&#146;s network programming time.&#160; We were concerned that since the program contained the use of the &#147;F-word&#148; (indecent material as defined by the FCC) airing the programming could result in a fine or other negative consequences for one or more of our ABC stations.&#160; In February&nbsp;2005, the FCC dismissed all complaints filed against ABC stations regarding this program.&#160; The FCC&#146;s decision justified what some may consider indecent material as appropriate in the context of the program.&#160; Although this ruling has expanded the programming opportunities of our stations, it still leaves us at risk because what might be determined as legitimate context by us may not be deemed so by the FCC and the FCC will not rule&nbsp;beforehand as this may be considered a restriction of free speech.&#160; For example, in September&nbsp;2006, we preempted a CBS network documentary on the events that happened on September&nbsp;11, 2001 because &#160;the</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12<a name="PB_12_154503_141"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\JMS\105933\11-2081-1\task4529165\2081-1-ba-05.htm',USER='105933',CD='Mar  2 20:41 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">program contained what some have argued is indecent material and the FCC would not provide, in advance of the airing of the documentary, any guidance on whether that material was appropriate in the context of the program.&#160; In 2007, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that the FCC&#146;s indecency policy regarding &#147;fleeting expletives&#148; was arbitrary and capricious when the FCC determined that &#147;fleeting expletives&#148; aired during the <i>Golden Globes</i> and <i>Billboard Music Awards</i> violated its indecency rules.&#160; The FCC challenged the decision and the case was argued before the Supreme Court in November&nbsp;2008.&#160; Also in 2008 the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit rejected an FCC decision concluding, among other things, that a fleeting display of nudity during the Superbowl halftime show was indecent.&#160; On April&nbsp;28, 2009, the Supreme Court overturned the <i>Golden Globes</i> and <i>Billboard Music Awards</i> decision of the Second Circuit and held that the FCC had adequately justified its departure from prior decisions in determining that it could sanction a station for a single &#147;F-word&#148; or &#147;S-word&#148; broadcast on that station.&#160; However, the Supreme Court also remanded the case back to the Second Circuit for further consideration to resolve any First Amendment Constitutional issues raised by the FCC&#146;s enforcement policy.&#160; On May&nbsp;16, 2009, the Supreme Court remanded the Superbowl halftime show case to the Third Circuit in order to consider the impact of the Supreme Court&#146;s <i>Golden Globes</i> and <i>Billboard Music Awards</i> decision and to consider the same First Amendment issues that were remanded to the Second Circuit.&#160; On July&nbsp;13, 2010, the Second Circuit struck down the FCC&#146;s indecency policy in its entirety.&#160; It remains unclear at this point whether the Supreme Court will hear the case.&#160; Additionally, other FCC indecency decisions have been challenged in federal appellate courts, and those cases are pending.&#160; These decisions and the FCC&#146;s unclear policy make it difficult for us to determine what may be indecent programming.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Ownership Matters</font></i></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">. &#160;The Communications Act prohibits the assignment of a broadcast license or the transfer of control of a broadcast license without the prior approval of the FCC.&#160; In determining whether to permit the assignment or transfer of control of, or the grant or renewal of, a broadcast license, the FCC considers a number of factors pertaining to the licensee, including compliance with various rules&nbsp;limiting common ownership of media properties, the &#147;character&#148; of the licensee and those persons holding &#147;attributable&#148; interests in that licensee and compliance with the Communications Act&#146;s limitations on alien ownership.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To obtain the FCC&#146;s prior consent to assign a broadcast license or transfer control of a broadcast license, appropriate applications must be filed with the FCC.&#160; If the application involves a &#147;substantial change&#148; in ownership or control, the application must be placed on public notice for a period of approximately 30 days during which petitions to deny the application may be filed by interested parties, including members of the public.&#160; If the application does not involve a &#147;substantial change&#148; in ownership or control, it is a &#147;pro forma&#148; application.&#160; The &#147;pro forma&#148; application is not subject to petitions to deny or a mandatory waiting period, but is nevertheless subject to having informal objections filed against it.&#160; If the FCC grants an assignment or transfer application, interested parties have approximately 30 days from public notice of the grant to seek reconsideration or review of the grant.&#160; Generally, parties that do not file initial petitions to deny, or informal objections against the application, face difficulty in seeking reconsideration or review of the grant.&#160; The FCC normally has an additional 10 days to set aside such grant on its own motion.&#160; When passing on an assignment or transfer application, the FCC is prohibited from considering whether the public interest might be served by an assignment or transfer to any party other than the assignee or transferee specified in the application.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC generally applies its ownership limits to &#147;attributable&#148; interests held by an individual, corporation, partnership or other association.&#160; In the case of corporations holding, or through subsidiaries controlling, broadcast licenses, the interests of officers, directors and those who, directly or indirectly, have the right to vote 5% or more of the corporation&#146;s stock (or 20% or more of such stock in the case of insurance companies, investment companies and bank trust departments that are passive investors) are generally attributable.&#160; In August&nbsp;1999, the FCC revised its attribution and multiple ownership rules&nbsp;and adopted the equity-debt-plus rule&nbsp;that causes certain creditors or investors to be attributable owners of a station.&#160; Under this rule, a major programming supplier (any programming supplier that provides more than 15% of the station&#146;s weekly programming hours) or same-market media entity will be an attributable owner of a station if the supplier or same-market media entity holds debt or equity, or both, in the station that is greater than 33% of the value of the station&#146;s total debt plus equity.&#160; For the purposes of this rule, equity includes all stock, whether voting or non-voting, and equity held by insulated limited partners in partnerships.&#160; Debt includes all liabilities whether long-term or short-term.&#160; In addition, LMAs are attributable where a licensee owns a television station and programs more than 15% of another television station in the same market.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Communications Act prohibits the issuance of a broadcast license to, or the holding of a broadcast license by, any corporation of which more than 20% of the capital stock is owned of record or voted by non-U. S. citizens or their representatives or by a foreign government or a representative thereof, or by any corporation organized under the laws of a foreign country (collectively, aliens).&#160; The Communications Act also authorizes the FCC, if the FCC determines that it would be in the public interest, to prohibit the issuance of a broadcast license to, or the holding of a broadcast license by, any corporation directly or indirectly controlled by any other corporation of which more than 25% of the capital stock is owned of record or voted by aliens.&#160; The FCC has issued interpretations of existing law under which these restrictions in modified form apply to other forms of business organizations, including partnerships.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">13<a name="PB_13_154529_7608"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\JMS\105933\11-2081-1\task4529165\2081-1-ba-05.htm',USER='105933',CD='Mar  2 20:41 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of these provisions, the licenses granted to our subsidiaries by the FCC could be revoked if, among other restrictions imposed by the FCC, more than 25% of our stock were directly or indirectly owned or voted by aliens.&#160; Sinclair and its subsidiaries are domestic corporations, and the members of the Smith family (who together hold approximately 82.1% of the common voting rights of Sinclair) are all United States citizens.&#160; Our amended and restated Articles of Incorporation (the Amended Certificate) contain limitations on alien ownership and control that are substantially similar to those contained in the Communications Act.&#160; Pursuant to the Amended Certificate, we have the right to repurchase alien-owned shares at their fair market value to the extent necessary, in the judgment of the Board of Directors, to comply with the alien ownership restrictions.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In February&nbsp;2008, the FCC released a Report and Order that, with the exception of the newspaper/broadcast cross-ownership rule, essentially re-adopts the ownership rules&nbsp;the FCC originally introduced in 1999 and has enforced since then.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The relevant 2008 ownership rules&nbsp;are as follows:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Radio/Television Cross-Ownership Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The FCC&#146;s radio/television cross-ownership rule&nbsp;(the &#147;one to a market&#148; rule) generally permits a party to own a combination of up to two television stations and six radio stations in the same market, depending on the number of independent media voices in the market.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Newspaper/Broadcast Cross-Ownership Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The FCC&#146;s rule&nbsp;generally prohibits the common ownership of a radio or television broadcast station and a daily newspaper in the same market.&#160; However, the FCC will presume that, in the top 20 DMAs, it is not inconsistent with the public interest for one entity to own a daily newspaper and a radio station or, under the following circumstances, a daily newspaper and a television station if: (1)&nbsp;the television station is not ranked among the top-four stations in the DMA and (2)&nbsp;at least eight independent &#147;major media voices&#148; remain in the DMA.&#160; The FCC will presume that all other newspaper/broadcast mergers are not in the public interest, but it will allow applicants to seek a waiver and rebut this presumption by clear and convincing evidence that, post-merger, the merged entity will increase the diversity of independent news outlets and increase competition among independent news sources in the relevant market.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Dual Network Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The four major television networks, FOX, ABC, CBS and NBC, are prohibited, absent a waiver, from merging with each other.&#160; In May&nbsp;2001, the FCC amended its dual network rule&nbsp;to permit the four major television networks to own, operate, maintain or control other television networks, such as The CW or MyNetworkTV.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">National Ownership Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; As of 2004, by statute, the national television viewing audience reach cap is 39%.&#160; Under this rule, where an individual or entity has an attributable interest in more than one television station in a market, the percentage of the national television viewing audience encompassed within that market is only counted once.&#160; Additionally, since historically, very high frequency, or VHF stations (channels 2 through 13) have shared a larger portion of the market than ultra high frequency, or UHF stations (channels 14 through 69), only half of the households in the market area of any UHF station are included when calculating an entity&#146;s national television viewing audience (commonly referred to as the UHF discount). Due to the elimination of the analog signal and switch to digital in 2009, the FCC has indicated that it may institute a future proceeding to assess whether it should alter or eliminate the UHF discount.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All but one of the stations we own and operate, or to which we provide programming services, are UHF.&#160; We reach approximately 22% of U. S. television households or 11.3% taking into account the FCC&#146;s UHF discount.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.35pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Local Television (Duopoly) Rule</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; A party may own television stations in adjoining markets, even if there is Grade B (discussed below) overlap between the two stations&#146; broadcast signals and generally may own two stations in the same market:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.35pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">if there is no Grade B overlap between the stations; or</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">if the market containing both the stations will contain at least eight independently owned full-power television stations post-merger (the eight voices test) and not more than one station is among the top-four ranked stations in the market.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.35pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, a party may request a waiver of the rule&nbsp;to acquire a second or third station in the market if the station to be acquired is economically distressed or not yet constructed and there is no party who does not own a local television station who would purchase the station for a reasonable price.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.35pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There are three grades of service for traditional television broadcasts, City (strongest), Grade A and Grade B (least strong); and the signal decreases in strength the further away the viewer is from the broadcast antenna tower.&#160; Generally, it is not as easy for viewers with properly installed outdoor antennas to receive a Grade B signal, as it is to receive a Grade A or City Grade signal.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Antitrust Regulation</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; The Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Trade Commission have increased their scrutiny of the television industry since the adoption of the 1996 Act and have reviewed matters related to the concentration of ownership within markets (including LMAs) even when ownership or the LMA in question is permitted under the laws administered by the FCC or </font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">14<a name="PB_14_154555_8146"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\JMS\105933\11-2081-1\task4529165\2081-1-ba-05.htm',USER='105933',CD='Mar  2 20:41 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">by FCC rules&nbsp;and regulations.&#160; The DOJ takes the position that an LMA entered into in anticipation of a station&#146;s acquisition with</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the proposed buyer of the station constitutes a change in beneficial ownership of the station which, if subject to filing under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Anti Trust Improvements Act, cannot be implemented until the waiting period required by that statute has ended or been terminated.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Expansion of our broadcast operations on both a local and national level will continue to be subject to the FCC&#146;s ownership rules, DOJ review and any changes the FCC or Congress may adopt.&#160; At the same time, any further relaxation of the FCC&#146;s ownership rules, which could occur if the rules&nbsp;adopted in 2008 are declared unenforceable, may increase the level of competition in one or more markets in which our stations are located, more specifically to the extent that any of our competitors may have greater resources and thereby may be in a superior position to take advantage of such changes.&#160; Conversely, any such relaxation or invalidation of such rules&nbsp;may provide us the opportunity to expand should we have the resources and find the terms advantageous.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Local Marketing Agreements</font></i></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of our stations have entered into what have commonly been referred to as local marketing agreements or LMAs.&#160; One typical type of LMA is a programming agreement between two separately owned television stations serving the same market, whereby the licensee of one station programs substantial portions of the broadcast day and sells advertising time during such programming segments on the other licensee&#146;s station subject to the latter licensee&#146;s ultimate editorial and other controls.&#160; We believe these arrangements allow us to reduce our operating expenses and enhance profitability.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If we are required to terminate or modify our LMAs, our business could be affected in the following ways:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Losses on investments</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; As part of our LMA arrangements, we own the non-license assets used by the stations with which we have LMAs.&#160; If certain of these LMA arrangements are no longer permitted, we would be forced to sell these assets, restructure our agreements or find another use for them.&#160; If this happens, the market for such assets may not be as good as when we purchased them and, therefore, we cannot be certain that we will recoup our original investments.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Termination penalties</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; If the FCC requires us to modify or terminate existing LMAs before the terms of the LMAs expire, or under certain circumstances, we elect not to extend the terms of the LMAs, we may be forced to pay termination penalties under the terms of some of our LMAs.&#160; Any such termination penalty could be material.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following paragraphs discuss various proceedings relevant to our LMAs.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 1999, the FCC established a new local television ownership rule.&#160; LMAs fell under this rule, however the rule&nbsp;grandfathered LMAs that were entered into prior to November&nbsp;5, 1996, and permitted the applicable stations to continue operations pursuant to the LMAs until the conclusion of the FCC&#146;s 2004 biennial review.&#160; The FCC stated it would conduct a case-by-case review of grandfathered LMAs and assess the appropriateness of extending the grandfathering periods.&#160; The FCC did not initiate any review of grandfathered LMAs in 2004 or as part of its 2006 quadrennial review.&#160; We do not know when, or if, the FCC will conduct any such review of grandfathered LMAs.&#160; For LMAs executed on or after November&nbsp;5, 1996, the FCC required compliance with the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;by August&nbsp;6, 2001.&#160; We challenged the 1999 rules&nbsp;in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit (D.C. Circuit), resulting in the exclusion of post-November&nbsp;5, 1996 LMAs from the 1999 rules.&#160; In 2002, the D.C. Circuit ruled in <i>Sinclair Broadcast Group,&nbsp;Inc. v. F.C.C</i>., 284 F.3d 114 (D.C. Cir. 2002) that the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;was arbitrary and capricious and sent the rule&nbsp;back to the FCC for further refinement.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2003, the FCC revised its ownership rules, including the local television ownership rule; however the U. S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit (Third Circuit) did not enable the 2003 rules&nbsp;to become effective and sent the 2003 rules&nbsp;back to the FCC for further refinement.&#160; Due to the court decisions, the FCC concluded the 1999 rules&nbsp;could not be justified as necessary in the public interest and as a result, we took the position that an issue exists regarding whether the FCC has any current legal right to enforce any rules prohibiting the acquisition of television stations.&#160; Several parties, including us, filed petitions with the Supreme Court of the United States seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme Court denied the petitions in June&nbsp;2005.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In July&nbsp;2006, the FCC released a Further Notice of Proposed Rule&nbsp;Making seeking comment on how to address the issues raised by the Third Circuit&#146;s decision.&#160; In January&nbsp;2008, the FCC released an order containing ownership rules&nbsp;that re-adopted the 1999 rules.&#160; On February&nbsp;29, 2008, several parties, including us, separately filed petitions for review in a number of federal appellate courts challenging the 1999 rules.&#160; Those petitions were consolidated in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit (Ninth Circuit) and in November&nbsp;2008, transferred by the Ninth Circuit to the Third Circuit where the proceedings are still pending.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On November&nbsp;15, 1999, we entered into an agreement to acquire WMYA-TV (formerly WBSC-TV) in Anderson, South Carolina from Cunningham Broadcasting Corporation (Cunningham), but that transaction was denied by the FCC.&#160; Since none of the FCC rule&nbsp;changes ever became effective, we filed a petition for reconsideration with the FCC and amended our application to acquire the </font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15<a name="PB_15_154645_7091"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\JMS\105933\11-2081-1\task4529165\2081-1-ba-05.htm',USER='105933',CD='Mar  2 20:41 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">license of WMYA-TV.&#160; We also filed applications in November&nbsp;2003 to acquire the license assets of the remaining five Cunningham stations: WRGT-TV, Dayton, Ohio; WTAT-TV, Charleston, South Carolina; WVAH-TV, Charleston, West Virginia; WNUV-TV, Baltimore, Maryland; and WTTE-TV, Columbus, Ohio.&#160; Rainbow/PUSH filed a petition to deny these five applications and to revoke all of our licenses.&#160; The FCC dismissed our applications and denied the Rainbow/PUSH petition due to the abovementioned 2003 Third Circuit decision.&#160; Rainbow/PUSH filed a petition for reconsideration of that denial and we filed an application for review of the dismissal.&#160; In 2005, we filed a petition with the D. C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC to take final action on our applications, but that petition was dismissed.&#160; On January&nbsp;6, 2006, we submitted a motion to the FCC requesting that it take final action on our applications.&#160; The applications and the associated petition to deny are still pending.&#160; We believe the Rainbow/PUSH petition is without merit.&#160; On February&nbsp;8, 2008, we filed a petition with the D.C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC to act on our applications and cease its use of the 1999 rules.&#160; In July&nbsp;2008, the D.C. Circuit transferred the case to the Ninth Circuit, and we filed a petition with the D.C. Circuit challenging that decision; however, it was denied.&#160; We also filed with the Ninth Circuit a motion to transfer that case back to the D.C. Circuit.&#160; In November&nbsp;2008, the Ninth Circuit consolidated and sent our petition seeking final FCC action on our applications to the Third Circuit.&#160; In December&nbsp;2008, we agreed voluntarily with the parties to our proceeding to dismiss our petition seeking final FCC action on our applications.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">The Satellite Home Viewer Act (SHVA), The Satellite Home Viewer Improvement Act (SHVIA) and the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and Reauthorization Act (SHVERA)</font></i></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 1988, Congress enacted the Satellite Home Viewer Act (SHVA), which enabled satellite carriers to provide broadcast programming to those satellite subscribers who were unable to obtain broadcast network programming over-the-air.&#160; SHVA did not permit satellite carriers to retransmit local broadcast television signals directly to their subscribers.&#160; The Satellite Home Viewer Improvement Act of 1999 (SHVIA) revised SHVA to reflect changes in the satellite and broadcasting industry.&#160; This legislation allowed satellite carriers, until December&nbsp;31, 2004, to provide local television signals by satellite within a station market, and effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, required satellite carriers to carry all local signals in any market where they carry any local signals.&#160; On or before July&nbsp;1, 2001, SHVIA required all television stations to elect to exercise certain &#147;must carry&#148; or &#147;retransmission consent&#148; rights in connection with their carriage by satellite carriers.&#160; We have entered into compensation agreements granting the two primary satellite carriers retransmission consent to carry all our stations.&#160; In December&nbsp;2004, President Bush signed into law the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and Reauthorization Act (SHVERA).&#160; SHVERA extended, until December&nbsp;31, 2009, the rights of broadcasters and satellite carriers under SHVIA to retransmit local television signals by satellite.&#160; On February&nbsp;9, 2009, a bill was introduced in the House of Representatives to extend this deadline for one year after enactment of the bill, which remains pending.&#160; SHVERA also authorized satellite delivery of distant network signals, significantly viewed signals and local low-power television station signals into local markets under defined circumstances.&#160; With respect to digital signals, SHVERA established a process to allow satellite carriers to retransmit distant network signals and significantly viewed signals to subscribers under certain circumstances.&#160; In November&nbsp;2005, the FCC completed a rulemaking proceeding enabling the satellite carriage of &#147;significantly viewed&#148; signals.&#160; In December&nbsp;2005, the FCC concluded a study, as required by SHVERA, regarding the applicable technical standards for determining when a subscriber may receive a distant digital network signal.&#160; The carriage of programming from two network stations to a local market on the same satellite system could result in a decline in viewership of the local network station, adversely impacting the revenues of our affected owned and programmed stations.&#160; Congress extended SHVERA until December&nbsp;31, 2014.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Must Carry/Retransmission Consent</font></i></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to the Cable Act of 1992, television broadcasters are required to make triennial elections to exercise either certain &#147;must-carry&#148; or &#147;retransmission consent&#148; rights in connection with their carriage by cable systems in each broadcaster&#146;s local market.&#160; Prior to October&nbsp;1, 2008, we elected retransmission consent with respect to all our stations for the period January&nbsp;1, 2009 through December&nbsp;31, 2011.&#160; By electing the must-carry rights, a broadcaster demands carriage and receives a specific channel on cable systems within its DMA, in general, as defined by the Nielsen DMA Market and Demographic Rank Report of the prior year.&#160; These must-carry rights are not absolute and their exercise is dependent on variables such as:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the number of activated channels on a cable system;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the location and size of a cable system; and</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the amount of programming on a broadcast station that duplicates the programming of another broadcast station carried by the cable system.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Therefore, under certain circumstances, a cable system may decline to carry a given station.&#160; Alternatively, if a broadcaster chooses to exercise retransmission consent rights, it can prohibit cable systems from carrying its signal or grant the appropriate cable system the authority to retransmit the broadcast signal for a fee or other consideration.&#160; The FCC has clarified that cable systems need only carry a broadcast station&#146;s primary video stream and not any of the station&#146;s other programming streams in those situations where a station chooses to transmit multiple programming streams.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16<a name="PB_16_154906_455"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\JMS\105933\11-2081-1\task4529165\2081-1-ba-05.htm',USER='105933',CD='Mar  2 20:41 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Syndicated Exclusivity/Territorial Exclusivity</font></i></b></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC&#146;s syndicated exclusivity rules&nbsp;allow local broadcast television stations to demand that cable operators black out syndicated non-network programming carried on &#147;distant signals&#148; (i.e. signals of broadcast stations, including so-called &#147;superstations&#148;, which serve areas substantially removed from the cable systems&#146; local community).&#160; The FCC&#146;s network non-duplication rules&nbsp;allow local broadcast, network affiliated stations to require that cable operators black out duplicate network programming carried on distant signals.&#160; However, in a number of markets in which we own or program stations affiliated with a network, a station that is affiliated with the same network in a nearby market is carried on cable systems in our markets.&#160; This is not necessarily a violation of the FCC&#146;s network non-duplication rules.&#160; However, the carriage of two network stations on the same cable system could result in a decline of viewership, adversely affecting the revenues of our owned or programmed stations.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Digital Television</font></i></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC has taken a number of steps to implement digital television (DTV) broadcasting services and has ruled that television broadcast licensees may use their digital channels for a wide variety of services such as HD television, multiple standard definition television programming, audio, data and other types of communications, subject to the requirement that each broadcaster provide at least one free video channel equal in quality to the current technical standard and further subject to the requirement that broadcasters pay a fee of 5% of gross revenues from any DTV ancillary or supplementary service for which there is a subscription fee or for which the licensee receives a fee from a third party.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">DTV channels are generally located in the range of channels from channel 2 through channel 51.&#160; All commercial stations were required to begin digital broadcasting on May&nbsp;1, 2002.&#160; In 2005, Congress passed legislation establishing a hard deadline of February&nbsp;17, 2009 by which broadcasters were required to cease using their analog channel.&#160; On February&nbsp;4, 2009, Congress passed the &#147;DTV Delay Act&#148; that extended the date for the completion of the DTV transition from February&nbsp;17, 2009 to June&nbsp;12, 2009.&#160; All of the television stations we own or to which we provide services are currently operating on authorized post-transition digital facilities.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We operate our television stations at different power levels pursuant to our FCC licenses, applicable permits or special temporary authority granted by the FCC.&#160; The following table is a summary of our operating status as of February&nbsp;28, 2011:</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="93%" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:.25in;width:93.34%;">
<tr>
<td width="83%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:83.4%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">DTV&nbsp;Operating&nbsp;Status</font></b></p>    </td>
<td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.68%;">
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>    </td>
<td width="12%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:12.86%;">
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">#&nbsp;of&nbsp;Stations</font></b></p>    </td>
<td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.08%;">

<tr>

<td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.68%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>    </td>

<td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.08%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>    </td>   </tr>
<tr>
<td width="83%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:83.4%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Owned stations   operating at full power, pending license approval</font></p>    </td>
<td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.68%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>    </td>
<td width="12%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:12.86%;">
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p>    </td>
<td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.08%;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>    </td>   </tr>
<tr>
<td width="83%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:83.4%;">
