<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the financial condition of those companies that advertise on our stations, including, among others, the automobile manufacturers and dealers, may be adversely affected and could result in a significant decline in our advertising revenue;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">our ability to pursue the acquisition of attractive television and non-television assets may be limited if we are unable to obtain any necessary additional capital on favorable terms, if at all;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">our ability to pursue the divestiture of certain television and non-television assets at attractive values may be limited;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the possibility that our business partners, such as our counterparties to our outsourcing and news share arrangements, could be negatively impacted and our ability to maintain these business relationships could also be impaired;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">our ability to refinance our existing debt on terms and at interest rates we find attractive, if at all, may be impaired;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">our ability to make certain capital expenditures may be significantly impaired; and</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">one or more of the lenders under our Bank Credit Agreement could refuse to fund its commitment to us or could fail and we may not be able to replace the financing commitment of any such lenders on favorable terms, or at all.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We must purchase television programming in advance based on expectations about future revenues.&#160; Actual revenues may be lower than our expectations.&#160; If this happens, we could experience losses that may make our securities less valuable.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">One of our most significant costs is television programming.&#160; Our ability to generate revenue to cover this cost may affect the value of our securities.&#160; If a particular program is not popular in relation to its costs, we may not be able to sell enough advertising time to cover the costs of the program.&#160; Since we generally purchase programming content from others rather than producing such content ourselves, we have limited control over the costs of the programming.&#160; We usually must purchase programming several years in advance and may have to commit to purchase more than one year&#146;s worth of programming.&#160; We may replace programs that are doing poorly before we have recaptured any significant portion of the costs we incurred or before we have fully amortized the costs.&#160; Any of these factors could reduce our revenues or otherwise cause our costs to escalate relative to revenues.&#160; These factors are exacerbated during a weak advertising market.&#160; Additionally, our business is subject to the popularity of the programs provided by the networks with which we have network affiliation agreements or which provide us programming.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We may lose a large amount of programming if a network terminates its affiliation or program service arrangement with us, which could increase our costs and/or reduce revenue.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our 58 television stations that we own and operate, or to which we provide (or for which we are provided) programming services or sales services, are affiliated with networks.&#160; The networks produce and distribute programming in exchange for each station&#146;s commitment to air the programming at specified times and for commercial announcement time during programming.&#160; The amount and quality of programming provided by each network varies.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The non-renewal or termination of any of our network affiliation agreements would prevent us from being able to carry programming of the relevant network.&#160; This loss of programming would require us to obtain replacement programming, which may involve higher costs and which may not be as attractive to our target audiences, resulting in reduced revenues.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">25<a name="PB_25_144450_6479"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='25',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-07.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:06 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Upon the termination of any of our network affiliation agreements, we would be required to establish a new network affiliation agreement for the affected station with another network or operate as an independent station.&#160; At such time, the remaining value of the network affiliation asset could become impaired and we would be required to write down the value of the asset to its estimated fair value.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We may not be able to negotiate our network affiliation agreements or program service arrangements at terms comparable to or more favorable than our current agreements upon their expiration.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As network affiliation agreements come up for renewal, we may not be able to negotiate terms comparable to or more favorable than our current agreements.&#160; On March&nbsp;25, 2010, we agreed to terms on a renewal of our eight ABC network affiliation agreements, expiring on August&nbsp;31, 2015.&#160; On December&nbsp;21, 2010, we agreed to terms of renewal of 20 FOX network affiliation agreements, expiring December&nbsp;31, 2012.&#160; Pursuant to the terms, we are required to pay an annual license fee to ABC and a programming fee to FOX for network programming.&#160; All 10 of our affiliation agreements with The CW expire on August&nbsp;31, 2011.&#160; We cannot predict the outcome of any future negotiations relating to our affiliation agreements or what impact, if any, they may have on our financial condition and results of operations.&#160; In addition, the impact of an increase in reverse network compensation payments, under which we compensate the network for programming pursuant to our affiliation agreements, may have a negative effect on our financial condition or results of operations.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We may not be able to renegotiate retransmission consent agreements at terms comparable to or more favorable than our current agreements and networks with which we are affiliated are currently, or in the future are expected to, require us to share revenue from retransmission consent agreements with them.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As certain retransmission consent agreements expire, we may not be able to renegotiate such agreements at terms comparable to or more favorable than our current agreements.&#160; This may cause revenues and/or revenue growth from our retransmission consent agreements to decrease under the renegotiated terms despite the fact that our current retransmission consent agreements include automatic annual fee escalators.&#160; In addition, certain of our networks or program service providers with which we are affiliated are currently, or in the future are expected to, require us to share revenue from retransmission consent agreements with them as part of renewing expiring affiliation agreements or pursuant to certain rights contained in existing affiliation agreements.&#160; There can be no assurances that the amounts shared will not increase at expiration of the current contracts.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The effects of the economic environment could require us to record an asset impairment of goodwill and FCC licenses.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We are required to analyze goodwill and certain other intangible assets for impairment.&#160; The accounting guidance establishes a method of testing goodwill and FCC licenses for impairment on an annual basis, or on an interim basis if an event occurs that would reduce the fair value of a reporting unit or an indefinite-lived asset below its carrying value.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At least annually, we test our goodwill and FCC licenses for impairment.&#160; To perform this test, we estimate the fair values of our reporting units for goodwill and FCC licenses using a combination of observed prices paid for similar assets and liabilities, discounted cash flow models and appraisals.&#160; We make certain critical estimates about the future revenue growth rates within each of our markets as well as the discount rates and comparable multiples that would be used by market participants in an arms-length transaction.&#160; If these growth rates or multiples decline or if the discount rate increases, our goodwill and/or FCC licenses&#146; carrying amounts could be in excess of the estimated fair value.&#160; An impairment of some or all of the value of these assets could result in a material effect on the consolidated statements of operations in the future.&#160; As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, we had approximately $660.0 million and $47.4 million of goodwill and broadcast licenses, respectively.&#160; As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, goodwill and broadcast licenses in aggregate represented 47.6% of our total assets.&#160; For additional information regarding impairments to our goodwill and broadcast licenses, see <i>Note</i>  <i>4</i>. <i>Goodwill, Broadcast Licenses and Other Intangible Assets</i> in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26<a name="PB_26_144513_2639"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-07.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:06 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Key officers and directors have financial interests that are different and sometimes opposite from ours and we may engage in transactions with these officers and directors that may benefit them to the detriment of other securityholders.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Some of our officers, directors and majority shareholders own stock or partnership interests in businesses that engage in television broadcasting, do business with us or otherwise do business that conflicts with our interests.&#160; They may transact some business with us upon approval by the independent members of our board of directors even if there is a conflict of interest or they may engage in business competitive to our business and those transactions may benefit the officers, directors or majority shareholders to the detriment of our securityholders.&#160; Each of David D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith, and J. Duncan Smith is an officer and director of Sinclair and Robert E. Smith is a director of Sinclair.&#160; Together, the Smiths hold shares of our common stock that control the outcome of most matters submitted to a vote of shareholders.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Smiths own a controlling interest in Bay Television,&nbsp;Inc., a company that owns WTTA-TV in Tampa/St. Petersburg, Florida, a television station which we program pursuant to an LMA.&#160; The Smiths also own businesses that lease real property and tower space to us and engage in other transactions with us.&#160; Trusts established by Carolyn C. Smith, a parent of the Smiths for the benefit of her and her grandchildren own Cunningham, our LMA partner in seven markets.&#160; In addition, we have been granted the rights to acquire, subject to applicable FCC rules&nbsp;and regulations, Cunningham (although the present rules&nbsp;and regulations of the FCC would not allow us to control the stations of Cunningham (the Cunningham Stations) if we continue to hold television stations in the same market as the Cunningham Stations).&#160; David D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith, Robert E. Smith and David B. Amy, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, together own interests in Allegiance Capital Limited Partnership, a limited partnership in which we also hold an interest.&#160; Frederick G. Smith owns an interest in Patriot Capital II, L.P., a limited partnership in which we also hold an interest.&#160; We can give no assurance that these transactions or any transactions that we may enter into in the future with our officers, directors or majority shareholders, have been, or will be, negotiated on terms as favorable to us as we would obtain from unrelated parties.&#160; Maryland law and our financing agreements limit the extent to which our officers, directors and majority shareholders may transact business with us and pursue business opportunities that we might pursue.&#160; These limitations do not, however, prohibit all such transactions.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For additional information regarding our related person transactions, see <i>Note 11. Related Person Transactions,</i> in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The Smiths exercise control over most matters submitted to a shareholder vote and may have interests that differ from other securityholders.&#160; They may, therefore, take actions that are not in the interests of other securityholders.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">David D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith and Robert E. Smith hold shares representing approximately 82.1% of the common stock voting rights of us as of February&nbsp;28, 2011 and, therefore, control the outcome of most matters submitted to a vote of shareholders, including, but not limited to, electing directors, adopting amendments to our certificate of incorporation and approving corporate transactions.&#160; The Smiths hold substantially all of the Class&nbsp;B Common Stock, which have ten votes per share.&#160; Our Class&nbsp;A Common Stock has only one vote per share.&#160; In addition, the Smiths hold half our board of directors&#146; seats and, therefore, have the power to exert significant influence over our corporate management and policies.&#160; The Smiths have entered into a stockholders&#146; agreement pursuant to which they have agreed to vote for each other as candidates for election to our board of directors until June&nbsp;13, 2015.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Although in the past the Smiths have recused themselves from related person transactions, circumstances may occur in which the interests of the Smiths, as the controlling securityholders, could be in conflict with the interests of other securityholders and the Smiths would have the ability to cause us to take actions in their interest.&#160; In addition, the Smiths could pursue acquisitions, divestitures or other transactions that, in their judgment, could enhance their equity investment, even though such transactions might involve risks to our other securityholders.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(See <i>Item 12. Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder Matters</i> and <i>Item 13. Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, </i>which will be included as part of our Proxy Statement for our 2011 Annual Meeting.)</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Significant divestitures by the Smiths could cause them to own or control less than 51% of the voting power of us, which would in turn give Cunningham the right to terminate the LMAs and other agreements with Cunningham due to a &#147;change in control&#148; of us.&#160; Any such terminations would have an adverse effect on our results of operations.&#160; The FCC&#146;s multiple ownership rules&nbsp;limit our ability to operate multiple television stations in some markets and may result in a reduction in our revenue or prevent us from reducing costs.&#160; Changes in these rules&nbsp;may threaten our existing strategic approach to certain television markets.&#160; See <i>Changes in rules&nbsp;on local marketing agreements</i> in the risk factor below.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">27<a name="PB_27_144538_2794"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='27',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-07.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:06 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Federal regulation of the broadcasting industry limits our operating flexibility, which may affect our ability to generate revenue or reduce our costs.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC regulates our business, just as it does all other companies in the broadcasting industry.&#160; We must ask the FCC&#146;s approval whenever we need a new license, seek to renew, assign or modify a license, purchase a new station, sell an existing station or transfer the control of one of our subsidiaries that holds a license.&#160; Our FCC licenses and those of the stations we program pursuant to LMAs are critical to our operations; we cannot operate without them.&#160; We cannot be certain that the FCC will renew these licenses in the future or approve new acquisitions in a timely manner, if at all.&#160; If licenses are not renewed or acquisitions are not approved, we may lose revenue that we otherwise could have earned.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, Congress and the FCC may, in the future, adopt new laws, regulations and policies regarding a wide variety of matters (including, but not limited to, technological changes in spectrum assigned to particular services) that could, directly or indirectly, materially and adversely affect the operation and ownership of our broadcast properties.&#160; (See <i>Item 1. Business.</i>)</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The FCC&#146;s multiple ownership rules&nbsp;limit our ability to operate multiple television stations in some markets and may result in a reduction in our revenue or prevent us from reducing costs.&#160; Changes in these rules&nbsp;may threaten our existing strategic approach to certain television markets.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Changes in rules&nbsp;on television ownership</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Congress passed a bill requiring the FCC to establish a national audience reach cap of 39% that was signed into law on January&nbsp;23, 2004.&#160; This law permits broadcast television owners to own more television stations nationally, potentially affecting our competitive position.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June&nbsp;2003, the FCC adopted new multiple ownership rules.&#160; In September&nbsp;2003, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit stayed the effectiveness of the rules.&#160; In June&nbsp;2004, the court issued a decision which upheld a portion of such rules&nbsp;and remanded the matter, including the local television ownership rule, to the FCC for further justification of the rules.&#160; The court left the stay of the 2003 rules&nbsp;in place pending the remand.&#160; Several parties, including us, filed petitions with the Supreme Court of the United States seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme Court denied the petitions in June&nbsp;2005.&#160; In July&nbsp;2006, as part of the FCC&#146;s statutorily required quadrennial review of its media ownership rules, the FCC released Further Notice of Proposed Rule&nbsp;Making seeking comment on how to address the issues raised by the Third Circuit&#146;s decision, including the local television ownership rules.&#160; In February&nbsp;2008, the FCC released an order containing its current ownership rules, which re-adopted its 1999 local television ownership rule.&#160; On February&nbsp;29, 2008, several parties, including us, separately filed petitions for review in a number of federal appellate courts challenging the FCC&#146;s current ownership rules.&#160; By lottery, those petitions were consolidated in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.&#160; In July&nbsp;2008, several parties, including us, filed motions to transfer the consolidated proceedings in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit and other parties requested transfer to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.&#160; In November&nbsp;2008, the Ninth Circuit transferred the consolidated proceedings to the Third Circuit where the proceedings are currently pending.&#160; These rules&nbsp;would not allow us to control the Cunningham Stations if we continue to hold television stations in the same markets as the Cunningham Stations and could force us to terminate or modify the LMAs with the Cunningham Stations.&#160; In addition, if Cunningham were to exercise its put rights under the acquisition and merger agreements and the LMAs, each as amended and/or restated, we may have to find a suitable third party to assume our purchase obligations because we are not permitted to purchase such stations under current FCC rules.&#160; We cannot assure you that we would be able to locate such a third party or that any such third party would continue the LMAs (or any alternative arrangements) with us on substantially similar terms that are as favorable to us or at all.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Changes in rules&nbsp;on local marketing agreements</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of our stations have entered into what have commonly been referred to as local marketing agreements or LMAs.&#160; One typical type of LMA is a programming agreement between two separately owned television stations serving the same market, whereby the licensee of one station programs substantial portions of the broadcast day and sells advertising time during such programming segments on the other licensee&#146;s station subject to the ultimate editorial and other controls being exercised by the latter licensee.&#160; We believe these arrangements allow us to reduce our operating expenses and enhance profitability.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 1999, the FCC established a new local television ownership rule&nbsp;and decided to attribute LMAs for ownership purposes.&#160; It grandfathered our LMAs that were entered into prior to November&nbsp;5, 1996, permitting the applicable stations to continue operations pursuant to the LMAs until the conclusion of the FCC&#146;s 2004 biennial review.&#160; The FCC stated it would conduct a case-by-case review of grandfathered LMAs and assess the appropriateness of extending the grandfathering periods.&#160; Subsequently, the FCC invited comments as to whether, instead of beginning</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">28<a name="PB_28_144605_8299"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='28',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-07.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:06 2011' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the review of the grandfathered LMAs in 2004, it should do so in 2006.&#160; The FCC did not initiate any review of grandfathered LMAs in 2004 or as part of its 2006 quadrennial review.&#160; We do not know when, or if, the FCC will conduct any such review of grandfathered LMAs.&#160; With respect to LMAs executed on or after November&nbsp;5, 1996, the FCC required that parties come into compliance with the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;by August&nbsp;6, 2001.&#160; We challenged the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit, and that court stayed the enforcement of the divestiture of the post-November&nbsp;5, 1996 LMAs.&#160; In 2002, the D.C. Circuit ruled that the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;was arbitrary and capricious and remanded the rule&nbsp;to the FCC.&#160; Currently, three of our LMAs are grandfathered under the local television ownership rule&nbsp;because they were entered into prior to November&nbsp;5, 1996 and the remainder are subject to the stay imposed by the D.C. Circuit.&#160; If the FCC were to eliminate the grandfathering of these three LMAs, or the D.C. Circuit were to lift its stay, we would have to terminate or modify these LMAs.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2003, the FCC revised its ownership rules, including the local television ownership rule. The effective date of the 2003 ownership rules&nbsp;was stayed by the U. S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit and the rules&nbsp;were remanded to the FCC.&#160; Because the effective date of the 2003 ownership rules&nbsp;had been stayed and, in connection with the adoption of those rules, the FCC concluded the 1999 rules&nbsp;could not be justified as necessary in the public interest, we took the position that an issue exists regarding whether the FCC has any current legal right to enforce any rules&nbsp;prohibiting the acquisition of television stations.&#160; Several parties, including us, filed petitions with the Supreme Court of the United States seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme Court denied the petitions in June&nbsp;2005.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On November&nbsp;15, 1999, we entered into a plan and agreement of merger to acquire through merger WMYA-TV in Anderson, South Carolina from Cunningham, but that transaction was denied by the FCC.&#160; In light of the change in the 2003 ownership rules, we filed a petition for reconsideration with the FCC and amended our application to acquire the license of WMYA-TV.&#160; We also filed applications in November&nbsp;2003 to acquire the license assets of, at the time, the remaining five Cunningham stations: WRGT-TV, Dayton, Ohio; WTAT-TV, Charleston, South Carolina; WVAH-TV, Charleston, West Virginia; WNUV-TV, Baltimore, Maryland; and WTTE-TV, Columbus, Ohio.&#160; The Rainbow/PUSH Coalition (Rainbow/PUSH) filed a petition to deny these five applications and to revoke all of our licenses on the grounds that such acquisition would violate the local television ownership rules.&#160; The FCC dismissed our applications in light of the stay of the 2003 ownership rules&nbsp;and also denied the Rainbow/PUSH petition.&#160; Rainbow/PUSH filed a petition for reconsideration of that denial and we filed an application for review of the dismissal.&#160; In 2005, we filed a petition with the U. S. Court of Appeals for the D. C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC to take final action on our applications, but that petition was dismissed.&#160; On January&nbsp;6, 2006, we submitted a motion to the FCC requesting that it take final action on our applications.&#160; Both the applications and the associated petition to deny are still pending.&#160; We believe the Rainbow/PUSH petition is without merit.&#160;&#160; On February&nbsp;8, 2008, we filed a petition with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC to take final action on these applications and cease its use of the 1999 local television ownership rule&nbsp;that it re-adopted as the permanent rule&nbsp;in 2008.&#160; In July&nbsp;2008, the D.C. Circuit transferred the case to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, and we filed a petition with the D.C. Circuit challenging that decision, which was denied.&#160; We also filed with the Ninth Circuit a motion to transfer that case back to the D.C. Circuit.&#160; In November&nbsp;2008, the Ninth Circuit consolidated our petition seeking final FCC action on our applications with the petitions challenging the FCC&#146;s current ownership rules&nbsp;and transferred the proceedings to the Third Circuit.&#160; In December&nbsp;2008, we agreed voluntarily with the parties to the proceeding to dismiss the petition seeking final FCC action on the applications.&#160; In addition, if Cunningham were to exercise its put rights under the acquisition and merger agreements and the LMAs, each as amended and/or restated, we may have to find a suitable third party to assume our purchase obligations because we are not permitted to purchase such stations under current FCC rules.&#160; In the event of any such assignments, new applications will have to be filed to reflect the third party as the applicant.&#160; In that event, upon the closing of the assignment to such third party, our appeals relating to the 1999 local television ownership rules&nbsp;with respect to our three non-grandfathered LMAs may be moot and the three non-grandfathered LMAs may be terminated.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If we are required to terminate or modify our LMAs, our business could be affected in the following ways:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Loss of revenues.&#160; If the FCC requires us to modify or terminate existing LMAs, we would lose some or all of the revenues generated from those LMAs.&#160; We would lose revenue because we will have less demographic options, a smaller audience distribution and lower revenue share to offer to advertisers.&#160; During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, we generated $118.5 million of net revenue from our nine LMAs.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Increased costs.&#160; If the FCC requires us to modify or terminate existing LMAs, our cost structure would increase.&#160; For example, we likely would incur increased programming costs because we will be competing with the separately owned station for syndicated programming.&#160; We may also need to add new employees.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">29<a name="PB_29_145321_2270"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='29',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-09.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:09 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Losses on investments</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; As part of our LMA arrangements, we own the non-license assets used by the stations with which we have LMAs.&#160; If certain of these LMA arrangements are no longer permitted, we would be forced to sell these assets, restructure our agreements or find another use for them.&#160; If this happens, the market for such assets may not be as good as when we purchased them and, therefore, we cannot be certain of a favorable return on our original investments.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Termination penalties</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">.&#160; If the FCC requires us to modify or terminate existing LMAs before the terms of the LMAs expire, or under certain circumstances, we elect not to extend the terms of the LMAs, we may be forced to pay termination penalties under the terms of some of our LMAs.&#160; Any such termination penalties could be material.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Alternative arrangements.&#160; If the FCC requires us to terminate the existing LMAs, we may enter into one or more alternative arrangements, such as outsourcing agreements, relating to the affected stations.&#160; Any such arrangements may be on terms that are less beneficial to us than the existing LMAs.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Use of outsourcing agreements</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition to our LMAs, we have entered into four (and may seek opportunities for additional) outsourcing agreements in which our stations provide or are provided various non-programming related services such as sales, operational and managerial services to or by other stations.&#160; Pursuant to these agreements, one of our stations in Nashville, Tennessee and our station in Cedar Rapids,&nbsp;Iowa currently provide services to another station in each&#146;s respective market and another party provides services to our stations in Peoria/Bloomington,&nbsp;Illinois and Rochester, New York.&#160; We believe this structure allows stations to achieve operational efficiencies and economies of scale, which should otherwise improve broadcast cash flow and competitive positions.&#160; While television joint sales agreements (JSAs) are not currently &#147;attributable&#148; under the FCC rules, on August&nbsp;2, 2004, the FCC released a notice of proposed rulemaking seeking comments on its tentative conclusion that JSAs should be attributable.&#160; We cannot predict the outcome of this proceeding, nor can we predict how any changes, together with possible changes to the ownership rules, would apply to our existing outsourcing agreements.&#160; If the FCC were to determine that our outsourcing arrangements were LMAs, we would have to terminate or restructure such arrangements on terms that may not be as advantageous to us as the current arrangements.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Failure of owner/licensee to exercise control</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC requires the owner/licensee of a station to maintain independent control over the programming and operations of the station.&#160; As a result, the owners/licensees of those stations with which we have LMAs or outsourcing agreements can exert their control in ways that may be counter to our interests, including the right to preempt or terminate programming in certain instances.&#160; The preemption and termination rights cause some uncertainty as to whether we will be able to air all of the programming that we have purchased under our LMAs and therefore, uncertainty about the advertising revenue that we will receive from such programming.&#160; In addition, if the FCC determines that the owner/licensee is not exercising sufficient control, it may penalize the owner licensee by a fine, revocation of the license for the station or a denial of the renewal of that license.&#160; Any one of these scenarios, especially the revocation of or denial of renewal of a license, might result in a reduction of our cash flow and an increase in our operating costs or margins.&#160; In addition, penalties might also affect our qualifications to hold FCC licenses, putting our own licenses at risk.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The pendency and indeterminacy of the outcome of these ownership rules, which may limit our ability to provide services to additional or existing stations pursuant to licenses, LMAs, outsourcing agreements or otherwise, expose us to a certain amount of volatility, particularly if the outcomes are adverse to us.&#160; Further, resolution of these ownership rules&nbsp;has been and will likely continue to be a cost burden and a distraction to our management and the continued absence of a resolution may have a negative effect on our business.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Competition from other broadcasters or other content providers and changes in technology may cause a reduction in our advertising revenues and/or an increase in our operating costs.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">New technology and the subdivision of markets</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cable providers, direct broadcast satellite companies and telecommunication companies are developing new technology that allows them to transmit more channels on their existing equipment to highly targeted audiences, reducing the cost of creating channels and potentially leading to the division of the television industry into ever more specialized niche markets.&#160; Competitors who target programming to such sharply defined markets may gain an advantage over us for television advertising revenues.&#160; The decreased cost of creating channels may also encourage new competitors to enter our markets and compete with us for advertising revenue.&#160; In addition, technologies that allow viewers to digitally record, store and play back television programming may decrease viewership of commercials as recorded by media measurement services such as Nielsen Media Research and, as a result, lower our advertising revenues.&#160; The broadcast and advertising industries have agreed on a ratings standard that includes live viewing plus</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">30<a name="PB_30_145321_6952"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='30',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-09.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:09 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">viewers who watch a program within 72 hours of its original appearance.&#160; However, the effects of new ratings system technologies, including &#147;people meters&#148; and &#147;set-top boxes,&#148; and the ability of such technologies to be a reliable standard that can be used by advertisers is currently unknown.&#160; In 2010, the Media Rating Council, an independent organization set-up to monitor rating services, revoked Nielsen&#146;s accreditation in the 154 markets it measures ratings exclusively by its diary methodology.&#160; Approximately 14 of our stations are currently diary only markets.&#160; In January&nbsp;2011, for certain markets, including our diary only markets, we entered into a contract with Rentrak Corporation, an alternative rating service provider, that uses set-top box television measurements to provide us additional measurement information to the ratings service Nielsen provides.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Since digital television technology allows broadcasting of multiple channels within the additional allocated spectrum, this technology could expose us to additional competition from programming alternatives.&#160; In addition, technological advancements and the resulting increase in programming alternatives, such as cable television, direct broadcast Satellite systems, pay-per-view, home video and entertainment systems, video-on-demand, mobile video and the Internet have also created new types of competition to television broadcast stations and will increase competition for household audiences and advertisers.&#160; We cannot provide any assurances that we will remain competitive with these developing technologies.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Types of competitors</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We also face competition from rivals that may have greater resources than we have.&#160; These include:</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">other local free over-the-air broadcast television and radio stations;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">telecommunication companies;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">cable and satellite system operators;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 76.5pt;text-indent:-22.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">print media providers such as newspapers, direct mail and periodicals;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">internet search engines, internet service providers and websites; and</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">competition from other emerging technologies including mobile television.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Deregulation</font></u></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Telecommunications Act of 1996 and subsequent actions by the FCC and the courts have removed some limits on station ownership, allowing telephone, cable and some other companies to provide video services in competition with us.&#160; In addition, the FCC has reallocated and auctioned off a portion of the spectrum for new services including fixed and mobile wireless services and digital broadcast services.&#160; As a result of these changes, new companies are able to enter our markets and compete with us.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We could be adversely affected by labor disputes and legislation and other union activity.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The cost of producing and distributing entertainment programming has increased substantially in recent years due to, among other things, the increasing demands of creative talent and industry-wide collective bargaining agreements.&#160; Although we generally purchase programming content from others rather than produce such content ourselves, our program suppliers engage the services of writers, directors, actors and on-air and other talent, trade employees and others, some of whom are subject to these collective bargaining agreements.&#160; If our program suppliers are unable to renew expiring collective bargaining agreements, it is possible that the affected unions could take action in the form of strikes or work stoppages.&#160; Failure to renew these agreements, higher costs in connection with these agreements or a significant labor dispute could adversely affect our business by causing delays in production that lead to declining viewers, and reductions in the profit margins of our programming and the amounts we can charge advertisers for time.&#160; Further, any changes in the existing labor laws, including the possible enactment of the Employee Free Choice Act, may further the realization of the foregoing risks.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Unrelated third parties may bring claims against us based on the nature and content of information posted on websites maintained by us.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We host internet services that enable individuals to exchange information, generate content, comment on our content, and engage in various online activities.&#160; The law relating to the liability of providers of these online services for activities of their users is currently unsettled both within the United States and internationally.&#160; Claims may be brought against us for defamation, negligence, copyright or trademark infringement, unlawful activity, tort, including personal injury, fraud, or other theories based on the nature and content of information that may be posted online or generated by our users.&#160; Our defense of such actions could be costly and involve significant time and attention of our management and other resources.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">31<a name="PB_31_145327_9801"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='31',FILE='C:\JMS\C900708\11-2081-1\task4532518\2081-1-ba-09.htm',USER='c900708',CD='Mar  4 07:09 2011' -->

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We may be subject to fines and other penalties related to violations of FCC indecency rules&nbsp;and other FCC rules&nbsp;and policies, the enforcement of which has increased in recent years, and complaints related to such violations may delay our renewal applications with the FCC.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We provide a significant amount of live news reporting that is provided by the broadcast networks or is controlled by our on-air news talent.&#160; Although both broadcast network and our on-air talent have generally been professional and careful in what they say, there is always the possibility that information may be reported that is inaccurate or even in violation of certain indecency rules&nbsp;promulgated by the FCC.&#160; In addition, entertainment programming provided by broadcast networks may contain content that is in violation of the indecency rules&nbsp;promulgated by the FCC.&#160; Because the interpretation by the courts and the FCC of the indecency rules&nbsp;is not always clear, it is sometimes difficult for us to determine in advance what may be indecent programming.&#160; We have insurance to cover some of the liabilities that may occur, but the FCC has enhanced its enforcement efforts relating to the regulation of indecency.&#160; In addition, in 2006, Congress dramatically increased the penalties for broadcasting indecent programming and potentially subjects broadcasters to license revocation, renewal or qualification proceedings in the event that they broadcast indecent material.&#160; We are currently subject to pending FCC inquiries and proceedings relating to alleged violations of indecency, sponsorship identification, children&#146;s programming and captioning rules.&#160; There can be no assurance that an incident that may lead to significant fines or other penalties by the FCC can be avoided.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, action on many license renewal applications, including those we have filed, has been delayed because of, among other reasons, the pendency of complaints that programming aired by the various networks contained indecent material and complaints regarding alleged violations of sponsorship identification, children&#146;s programming and captioning rules.&#160; As of February&nbsp;28, 2011, 15 of our renewal applications were subject to such complaints.&#160; We cannot predict when the FCC will address these complaints and act on the renewal applications.&#160; We continue to have operating authority until final action is taken on our renewal applications.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The FCC&#146;s National Broadband Plan may result in a loss of spectrum for our stations potentially adversely impacting our ability to compete.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC&#146;s National Broadband Plan contemplates the voluntary reallocation of spectrum from broadcasters for other purposes which may include wireless broadband. On November&nbsp;30, 2010, the FCC initiated a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking that seeks comments on three methods that would permit up to 120 MHz of television spectrum to be reallocated for wireless broadband use:&nbsp; (a)&nbsp;encouraging broadcasters &#147;voluntarily&#148; to return 120 MHz of spectrum to be auctioned for wireless broadband service, with some currently unknown portion of the proceeds to be paid to broadcasters; (b)&nbsp;adoption of rules&nbsp;to encourage two or more digital television stations to share the same 6 MHz channel, thus lessening the spectrum occupied by each station; and (c)&nbsp;to adopt new engineering rules&nbsp;which would make VHF channels more desirable for digital television operations, thus encouraging stations to move from their current UHF channels into the VHF band, freeing UHF spectrum for wireless broadband use.&nbsp;&nbsp; This initiative raises a number of issues that could impact the broadcast industry.&nbsp; We cannot predict whether any of these proposals will be adopted, or, if adopted, the form of such final rules&nbsp;or whether they would have an adverse impact on our ability to compete.&nbsp; Moreover, we cannot predict whether the FCC might adopt even more stringent requirements, or incentives to abandon current spectrum, if its initiatives are adopted but do have the desired result in freeing what the agency deems sufficient spectrum for wireless broadband use.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Costs of complying with changes in governmental laws and regulations may adversely affect our results of operations.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We cannot predict what other governmental laws or regulations will be enacted in the future, how future laws or regulations will be administered or interpreted or how future laws or regulations will affect us.&#160; Compliance with new laws or regulations, including proposed legislation to address climate change, or stricter interpretation of existing laws, may require us to incur significant expenditures or impose significant restrictions on us and could cause a material adverse effect on our results of operations.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The continuation of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan may negatively impact our advertising revenues and results of operations.&#160; Future conflicts, terrorist attacks or other acts of violence may have a similar effect.</font></b></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The commencement of the war in Iraq in 2002 and activities in Afghanistan resulted in a reduction of advertising revenues as a result of uninterrupted news coverage and/or general economic uncertainty.&#160; The continuation of these wars may have a similar negative impact on our advertising revenues and results of operations.&#160; If the United States becomes engaged in similar conflicts in the future, there may be a similar adverse effect on our results of operations.&#160; Also, any terrorist attacks or other acts of violence may have a similar negative effect on our business or results of operations.</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">32<a name="PB_32_145345_2440"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 1B.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</font></b><a name="Item1b_UnresolvedStaffComments_145356"></a></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 2.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; PROPERTIES</font></b><a name="Item2_Properties_145401"></a></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Generally, each of our stations has facilities consisting of offices, studios and tower sites.&#160; Transmitter and tower sites are located to provide maximum signal coverage of our stations&#146; markets.&#160; We believe that all of our properties, both owned and leased, are generally in good operating condition, subject to normal wear and tear and are suitable and adequate for our current business operations.&#160; The following is a summary of our principal owned and leased real properties.&#160; Approximately 67,000 square feet of the leased office and studio building is related to our corporate facilities.&#160; We believe that no one property represents a material amount of the total properties owned or leased.&#160; See <i>Item 1</i>. <i>Business,</i> for a listing of our station locations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 3.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></b><a name="Item3_LegalProceedings_145533"></a></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We are a party to lawsuits and claims from time to time in the ordinary course of business.&#160; Actions currently pending are in various stages and no material judgments or decisions have been rendered by hearing boards or courts in connection with such actions.&#160; After reviewing developments to date with legal counsel, our management is of the opinion that the outcome of our pending and threatened matters will not have a material adverse effect on our consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements of operations or consolidated statements of cash flows.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 4.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; REMOVED AND RESERVED</font></b><a name="Item4_RemovedAndReserved_145538"></a></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">33<a name="PB_33_145538_5340"></a></font></p>
<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>
</div>

<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><a href="#TableOfContents" title="Click to go to Table of Contents">Table of Contents</a></font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART&nbsp;II</font></b><a name="Partii_145551"></a></p>
<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 63.0pt;text-indent:-63.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 5.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></b><b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES</font></b><a name="Item5_MarketForRegistrantsCommonE_000039"></a></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 63.0pt;text-indent:-63.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:9.35pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our Class&nbsp;A Common Stock is listed for trading on the NASDAQ stock market under the symbol SBGI.&#160; Our Class&nbsp;B Common Stock is not traded on a public trading market or quotation system.&#160; The following tables set forth for the periods indicated the high and low closing sales prices on the NASDAQ stock market for our Class&nbsp;A Common Stock.</font></p>
<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
